title.narrative: Reducing the vulnerability of inter-state migrant workers in India to bonded labor and domestic servitude in destination and source states

description.narrative: Anti-Slavery International is raising awareness on the issue of human trafficking in India. In partnership with local non-governmental organizations, Anti-Slavery International is releasing and protecting bonded laborers and those in domestic servitude in India, and reducing their future vulnerabilities via enhanced awareness. Anti-Slavery International is improving access to statutory benefits and skills training; increasing the ability of workers to claim and assert their rights; and heightening oversight of workplaces and recruitment agencies. Anti-Slavery International is strengthening the ability of migrant workers to organize and advocate for their rights; conducting awareness and sensitization campaigns to spur legislative and policy action against bonded labor and domestic servitude; and advocating for India to ratify and implement the International Labor Organizations Convention 189 (The Rights of Domestic Workers).

title.narrative: Sustained Liberation: Using legal rights, the power of communities and reintegration of survivors to uproot systems of slavery in India

description.narrative: This 3-year program will work to create permanent resistance to slavery in over 270 networked communities, in 11 Districts of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar. It will promote effective mobilization of official systems and public awareness, to end toleration of slavery, neglect of victims, and impunity of perpetrators. Manav Sansadhan Evam Mahila Vikas Sansthan (MSEMVS) will manage work carried out by over 60 anti-slavery field workers. These teams have an extraordinary track record for liberating individuals (1,149 officially released since 2009) and creating sustained freedom (82 communities have achieved the benchmarks for slavery eradication since 2009). This program will build on these achievements: A further 58 communities will achieve the benchmarks for eradication and self-sustaining capacity. Community Vigilance Committee (CVC) actions will lead to rescue of 950+ victims, who will receive reintegration support. MSEMVS will liberate 400 children through transitional schools, and enable 200 women to earn enough income to repudiate debt bondage. FTS will complete post-intervention surveys in seven communities to verify the end of slavery and measure the development gains (freedom dividend). 75 new legal cases will be prosecuted, with 58+ arrests and 7+ convictions. 40 training events will improve the performance of judges, labor, transport and police officials. In at least 2 locations of concentrated sexual exploitation, a carefully designed intervention will curtail traffickers activities, rescue new arrivals and present viable options to victims. Frontline liberators will receive world-class training from FTS in publicizing testimony of slaves/former slaves, to challenge negligent officials and awaken public conscience.

title.narrative: Global Peace Operations Initiative: UN National Investigation Officer, Centre for Land Warfare Studies (CLAWS)

description.narrative: The GPOI program enhances international capacity to effectively conduct United Nations and regional peace operations. International peace operations are strategically important to U.S. national security and foreign policy objectives. The GPOI program is the primary mechanism through which the United States contributes to strengthening global capacity to conduct peace operations. The program's partnerships emphasize institutional capacity-building relationships and seek to strengthen partner countries' capabilities to self-sufficiently train, deploy, employ, and sustain peacekeeping forces.

title.narrative: To reduce the vulnerability and level of labour exploitation and trafficking of local and inter-state migrant workers in India

description.narrative: Anti-Slavery International will aim to reduce bonded labor and trafficking into forced labor in the brick and agricultural industries in three Indian states. Activities will include: supporting released bonded laborers through legal assistance; facilitating the empowerment of workers through the formation of worker-led associations; advocating for wage reforms and improved conditions for workers at the local and national levels; assisting the registration of workers for social entitlements and benefits; and capacity building for non-governmental organizations on identification and release of bonded laborers.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Economic Support Fund

title.narrative: Combating trafficking through capacity building, training and sensitization of Police, Labour Officials, Anti Human Trafficking Units (AHTU) & Prosecution

description.narrative: The proposed project aims to strengthen and sustain anti-TIP partnerships, which have been initiated with various law enforcement agencies in the current running JTIP supported project (2010- Feb2013). This project will focus on prevalent forms of trafficking: child labor, bonded labor, sex slavery and forced marriages. It will provide legal and technical expertise, empower and build capacity of specialized newly initiated Anti Human Trafficking Units (AHTU) and facilitate inter-state police cooperation in 10 northern states, which are source areas for trafficking in India. It will focus on capacity building and training of prosecutors and it will strengthen Child Welfare Committees (CWC). The project will facilitate the sharing of information among law enforcement agencies in National Capital Region (NCR) of Delhi and the source areas for increased vigilance and cooperation to curb TIP while ensuring victims receive support and protection. The project will provide legal aid to victims while empowering and strengthening state legal aid institutions. It will create a 24x7 anti-trafficking response centre for technical and logistics support for interstate case interventions and ultimately integrate and institutionalize the centre into the governments tip response. The project aims to also to raise public awareness on trafficking.

title.narrative: Building Capacity to Address Human Trafficking

description.narrative: India is a source, destination, and transit country for men, women, and children subjected to forced labor and sex trafficking. Forced labor constitutes Indias largest trafficking problem: men, women, and children in debt bondagesometimes inherited from previous generationsare forced to work in brick kilns, rice mills, embroidery factories, and agriculture. Experts estimate millions of adults and children are victims of forced labor in India, but comprehensive labor surveys have not been conducted to assess the presence of victims of forced labor in commodity supply chains that end in the United States. This project is designed to identify and remediate cases of human trafficking, and forced/bonded labor among adults working in supply chains, and establish an outcome-based monitoring and evaluation platform to help stakeholders track impact across northern India. The project aims to develop real-time data sharing tools to help labor inspectorates and other government enforcement actors improve human trafficking efforts. GoodWeave will work directly with the Jaipur Anti-Human Trafficking Hunt at the local government level in Rajasthan.

title.narrative: Documentation of 16th-17th-Century Mughal Monuments on the Grand Trunk Road

description.narrative: One of Asia's longest and oldest major trade routes, the Grand Trunk Road links Central Asia and the Indian subcontinent, from Afghanistan to Bangladesh. This project, which focuses on the segment between Agra and Lahore, involves the documentation of 60 monuments at 15 historic sites in India and Pakistan, the collection of oral histories from local communities, and the creation of an online digital platform for sharing the documentation.

title.narrative: Activating the Bonded Labour System Abolition Act

description.narrative: FTS will work to combat forced labor in the form of debt bondage by working with local government authorities to effectively implement India's Bonded Labour System Abolition Act in three Indian states, particularly in the agriculture and brick kiln sectors. Activities will include providing economic and social services to survivors of labor trafficking, conducting a survey of bonded labor in target districts, developing a case management system to track bonded labor cases, and capacity building for Indian law enforcement and legal professionals.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement
International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement

title.narrative: Strengthening the State Government

description.narrative: India is a source, destination, and transit country for men, women, and children subjected to forced labor and sex trafficking. Forced labor constitutes Indias largest trafficking problem: men, women, and children in debt bondagesometimes inherited from previous generationsare forced to work in brick kilns, rice mills, embroidery factories, and agriculture. Experts estimate millions of adults and children are victims of forced labor, and in Karnataka state, surveys show more than 30% of workers in manual labor industries are victims of forced labor. This project will equip front-line responders to respond effectively to bonded labor, ensuring that the government is proactively identifying cases and responding in a coordinated and timely manner. The project will engage with a host of local actors including district officials, anti-trafficking units, police officers, labor commissioners, public prosecutors, and judicial magistrates at the state magistrates level to encourage the state governments full buy-in and prioritization of human trafficking. Over the course of the project, hundreds of victims will be assisted and their cases will be filed, increasing local resiliency and lessening a source of illicit profit. This project will build upon local efforts and will work to reduce human trafficking and improve information sharing to target criminals and corrupt leaders and disrupt human trafficking. In addition, if successful, the project will see an increase in investigations and prosecutions, thereby serving as a deterrent to potential traffickers.

description.narrative: To support documentation of the 18th-century Balaji Ghat river front in Varanasi, the only pavilion serving multiple faiths on the banks of the Ganges River in Varanasi. The project involves assessment, photo documentation, archival research, and other activities in preparation for the buildings eventual restoration.
